Simon Munzert, Julia Ellingwood, Lisa Oswald, Richard Traunmüller

November 2025

Study summary

Online platforms rely on humans and AI systems to moderate toxic speech, yet AI models inevitably inherit the biases embedded in the human labels they learn from. Drawing on an original cross-national visual conjoint experiment including 19k respondents in 11 countries, we analyze over 150k human judgments of toxic social media posts. Across contexts, people broadly support keeping non-threatening speech online, but views on what counts as offensive or hateful diverge sharply. Strikingly, we can show that moderation decisions are heavily shaped by the rater’s stance on the issue at hand. This pervasive “myside bias” transcends ideology, topic, and geography. These results reveal a fundamental challenge for content moderation: when perceptions of harm and support for sanctioning are rooted in subjective viewpoints, no technical fix can yield universally legitimate enforcement. This calls for rethinking the design and legitimacy of automated enforcement in polarized environments.
